facts.text: The appeal is before the Supreme Court on a certificate of fitness granted by the Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, on a certificate of fitness granted by the Punjab High Court, the only question for determination is whether the provisions of s. 5 of the Limitation Act  9 of 1908

facts.text: The respondent was committed to the Court of Sessions to stand his trial under s. 493, or in the alternative under s. 495, of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: The respondent was charged with deceiving the appellant, who was not lawfully married to him, to believe that she was married, and in that belief had sexual intercourse with her.

anchor.surface_text: on the charge that he had, by deceit, cause the appellant who was number lawfully married to him to believe that she was so married, and in that belief had sexual intercourse with her. In the alternative, it was alleged that he

facts.text: In the alternative, the respondent was alleged to have married the appellant after concealing the fact that he was already married.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, it was alleged that he married, the appellant after companycealing the fact that he was already married. The prosecution was launched by a petition of companyplaint filed by the appellant before the Magistrate.

facts.text: The prosecution was launched by a petition of complaint filed by the appellant before the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution was launched by a petition of companyplaint filed by the appellant before the Magistrate. The respondent was tried by the Additional Sessions Judge, Gurdaspur, who by his judgment dated December 31, 1959, acquitted

facts.text: The respondent was tried by the Additional Sessions Judge, Gurdaspur.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was tried by the Additional Sessions Judge, Gurdaspur, who by his judgment dated December 31, 1959, acquitted him on the ground that the prosecution had failed to prove that there was a marriage between the

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Gurdaspur acquitted the respondent by judgment dated December 31, 1959 on the ground that the prosecution failed to prove marriage between complainant and accused.

anchor.surface_text: who by his judgment dated December 31, 1959, acquitted him on the ground that the prosecution had failed to prove that there was a marriage between the companyplainant and the accused. The appellant filed an application on April 22, 1960,

facts.text: The appellant filed an application on April 22, 1960 for special leave to appeal from the order of acquittal under s.417(3) of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an application on April 22, 1960, very much later than 60 days from the date of the order of acquittal, for special leave to appeal from that order, under s. 417 3  of the Code.

facts.text: In a memo appended to the application, it was stated that time in filing might be excluded because District Magistrate, Gurdaspur moved the Advocate-General for filing appeal under s.417 CrPC, but State Government declined and intimation received on April 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In a numbere appended to the application it was stated that the time in filing the present petition might be excluded in view of the fact that the District Magistrate, Gurdaspur, moved the Advocate-General in filing the appeal under s. 417, Criminal Procedure Code, which if filed would have obviated the necessity of filing this petition. But the State Government declined to file appeal and the intimation to this effect was received on April 1, 1960.

facts.text: A Division Bench of the High Court passed the order 'Admitted' on September 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The original letter is attached herewith from this date, it is within time. On this application, a Division Bench of the High Court passed the order Admitted, on September 1, 1960.

facts.text: When the appeal was placed for hearing before Falshaw and Grover, JJ, a preliminary objection was raised on behalf of the respondent that the appeal was out of time.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was placed for hearing before Falshaw and Grover, JJ, a preliminary objection was raised on behalf of the respondent that the appeal was out of time. While it was admitted on behalf of the appellant that the appeal was filed long after the period prescribed by sub. s.  4  of s. 417 of the Code,

facts.text: It was admitted on behalf of the appellant that the appeal was filed long after the period prescribed by sub-s. 4 of s.417 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: While it was admitted on behalf of the appellant that the appeal was filed long after the period prescribed by sub. s.  4  of s. 417 of the Code, it was argued that the delay companyld be companydoned under s. 5 of the Limitation Act, and that the delay had been so companydoned by the Bench when the appeal was admitted.

facts.text: The High Court held that no application had been made by the appellant for extension of the period of limitation and did not condone the delay when admitting.

anchor.surface_text: it was argued that the delay companyld be companydoned under s. 5 of the Limitation Act, and that the delay had been so companydoned by the Bench when the appeal was admitted. The Bench pointed out that as a matter of fact numberapplication had been made by the appellant for extension of the period of limitation for filing petition for special leave.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the appeal holding that s.5 of Limitation Act does not apply as sub-s.4 of s.417 is a special law per s.29(2) Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Court, on an elaborate examination of the provisions of the Code, and of the Limitation Act, came to the companyclusion that the bar of time prescribed by sub-s.  4  of s. 417 was a special law within the meaning of s. 29 2  of the Limitation Act, and that, therefore, s. 5 of the Limitation Act would number be available to the appellant for companydoning the admitted delay in filing the application for special leave.

facts.text: The appellant applied to the High Court and obtained the necessary certificate of fitness and appealed to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court numbericed a number of decisions of the different High Courts and preferred to accept the view that the provisions of sub-s.  4  of s. 417 of the Code were in the nature of a special law though the Code as a whole was a general law. In that view of the matter, the High Court dismissed the appeal on the ground that the application for special leave to appeal was barred by time. The appellant applied to the High Court and obtained the necessary certificate of fitness and has companye up to this Court on appeal from that order of the High Court.

facts.text: The High Court did not go into the merits of the controversy.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court naturally did number go into the merits of the companytroversy.

facts.text: Section 417 of the Code was recast by Act XXVI of 1955, for the first time making provision for appeal by private complainant from order of acquittal if special leave obtained.

anchor.surface_text: It will appear that the section, which was recast by Act XXVI of 1955, for the first time made provision for an appeal by a private companyplainant from an order of acquittal, if he obtained special leave to appeal from the High Court.

facts.text: Previous to the Amending Act of 1955, only the State Government could appeal from an order of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to the Amending Act aforesaid, it was only the State Government which companyld companye up in appeal from an order of acquittal.

arguments.claim: Provisions of sub-ss. 3 & 4 s.417 CrPC are special provisions/law distinct from general CrPC; prescribe 60-day bar different from Limitation Act Art.157.

anchor.surface_text: But the specific question with which we are here concerned is whether the provision contained in s. 417 4 of the Code is a special law. The whole Code is indeed a general law regulating the procedure in criminal trials generally,

arguments.claim: Legislature intended shorter 60-day period for private complainant appeals vs 3 months for state (Art.157), to curtail litigation post-acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: On a perusal of the bare provisions of the section and the history of the law on the subject, two things are clear namely,  1  that the legislature thought it expedient in the interest of justice and public policy that the period of six months allowed to the State Government

arguments.claim: Special law means provision for special cases/circumstances distinct from general rules, even within general code like CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: A special law, therefore, means a law enacted for special cases, in special circumstances, in contradistinction to the general rules of the law laid down, as applicable generally to all cases with which the general law deals.

arguments.claim: s.417(4) prescribes different limitation period from Limitation Act (no period for private appeals, vs Art.157 for state), so s.29(2)(b) excludes s.5.

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether it can be said that even though the provisions of s. 417 4  are a special law, they prescribe a different period of limitation from that prescribed by the First Scheduled of the Limitation Act, because s. 29 2  applies where there is a difference
